â€˜The Extreme Always Seems To Make An Impressionâ€™: Reviewing Heathers the Musical

By Emily Warner

Emily Warner (she/her) reviews Heathers the Musical.

Out of my head: Paul Merton

Paul Merton's new tour was disappointing; both in the comedian's lack of convincing punchlines, and in his over-reliance on his fellow performers.

Review: URY O'Sullivan and Mawn

A few teething problems aside, O'Sullivan and Mawn's new radio show is genuinely brilliant.

Blue/Orange

Blue/Orange takes you deeper in to the human mind with every second.

Deathwatch

Jean Genet's one act play about three prisoners, Green Eyes, Lefranc and Maurice.

Painting Liberty in Cuba

The 'Miami Five' produce a series of artworks to highlight injustice

Best Book: Escape From Camp 14

Biography of Shin Dong-Hyuk, the only known person in history to have escaped from a North Korean gulag

The price of culture

Even if art organisations do decide to throw themselves into the deep end of the private sector, the funding could never be a guaranteed safety net.

Damien Hirst: The Con Artist

Damien Hirst continues to be a divisive conceptual artist. With his new exhibition at the Tate Modern, Aggie Torrance explores why we shouldn't give up on Modern Art just yet. (Thumbnail credit Hirst with cast 'For the Love of God' which is encrusted with PS14m of diamonds. Image credit: Reuters )

Mystery Plays Rewind History

The producer of York's Myster Cycle Production, Liam Evans-Ford, speaks to Celia Scruby

Best Book - Smut

'Smut' takes the form of two short stories by Northern national treasure, Alan Bennett.

WeiWei's message

Weiwei's sunflower seeds still have a continuing power, investigates Agatha Torrance

Thoroughly Modern Millican

Sarah puts on, not for the first time, a very well written and skilfully performed show.

Pinter Double Bill: Moonlight and Celebration

It is certainly an acquired taste, but if one can appreciate that Pinter has not created this as a crowd pleaser then ironically I believe you can really enjoy it.

Yeomen of the Guard

Although falling below expectations, Yeomen of the Guard retained the light hearted frivolity of Gilbert and Sullivan, leaving the audience with the feel-good factor.

Spamalot

This production is able to stand up as a piece of entertainment by itself...and successfully incorporates the irresistible element of a musical.

In Pictures: Lucian Freud

By James Bithell

Lucian Freud in Pictures: Portraits (National Gallery until 27th May)

One Great Expectation

With the passing of Charles Dickens' bicentennial, Jonjo Lowe explores the author's works and their enduring relevance in the modern day (Thumbnail credit Charles Dickens)

Best Book

The term 'thriller' doesn't often go together with 'literary', but here the two collide in S. J. Watson's phenomenal debut novel

The Diary of Anne Frank

This is a respectful production of Anne Frank's Diary which draws strength from depicting the interplay between family relations, issues any family can relate to, creating a very real experience.

POSH

WARNING: Contains Spoilers!!

The Fantasist's Waltz

Welcome to the World of the Fantasist, where dreaming and reality are synonymous.

Norman Rea: Painterly Effluvia

Painterly Effluvia is the rather awe-inspiring title of the latest exhibition to grace the walls of the Norman Rea Gallery.

Into the Woods

It's not a flawless musical, but this was a brave, near flawless production, with an outstanding cast.

Twelfth Night

The confidence and comfort of the major characters onstage brought life and momentum to the play's hilarious twists of plot.

Omid Djalili

By James Bithell

Never lacking in energy, Djalili used topical humour, a wavering accent and intermittent belly dancing to set people rolling in the aisles.

Matilda The Musical

By James Bithell

This is a sensational theatrical adaption of Roald Dahl's cherished tale.

Dorian

Dorian is an innovative and enjoyable interpretation, which succeeds in elevating itself to the standard of professional theatre.

The Bigger Picture

David Hockney takes on the Yorkshire landscape with his iPad, Celia Scruby investigates

Derek Acorah: The Art of Unlocking the Mind

Derek Acorah contact the spirits of the dead and is one of the leading names in British mediumship.

Suggs: My Life Story

By James Bithell

An autobiography on-stage which is as full of madness as it is Madness.
